awd_titl_txt: CHS: Large: Collaborative Research: Computational Science for Improving Assessment of Executive Function in Children
awd_abstract_narration:
The identification of cognitive impairments in early childhood provides the best opportunity for successful remedial intervention, because brain plasticity diminishes with age.  Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a psychiatric neurodevelopmental disorder that is very hard to diagnose or tell apart from other disorders.  Symptoms include inattention, hyperactivity, or acting impulsively, all of which often result in poor performance in school and persist later in life.  In this project, an interdisciplinary team of computer and neurocognitive scientists will develop and implement transformative computational approaches to evaluate the cognitive profiles of young children and to address these issues.  The project will take advantage of both physical and computer based exercises already in place in 300 schools in the United States and involving thousands of children, many of whom have been diagnosed with ADHD or other learning disabilities.  Project outcomes will have important implications for a child's success in school, self-image, and future employment and community functioning.  The PIs will discover new knowledge about the role of physical exercise in cognitive training, including correlations between individual metrics and degree of improvement over time.  They will identify important new metrics and correlations currently unknown to cognitive scientists, which will have broad impact on other application domains as well.  And the PIs will develop an interdisciplinary course on computational cognitive science and one on user interfaces for neurocognitive experts.

The research will involve four thrusts.  The PIs will devise new human motion analysis and computer vision algorithms that can automatically assess embodied cognition during structured physical activities, and which will constitute a breakthrough in improving the accuracy and efficiency of cognitive assessments of young children.  Intelligent mining techniques will be used to discover new knowledge about the role of physical exercise in cognitive training and to find correlations between individual metrics and degree of improvement over time.  A methodology will be developed using advanced multimodal sensing to collect and process huge amounts of evidence based assessment data with intelligent mechanisms that learn about a child's executive function capabilities and help uncover possible causes of cognitive dysfunctions.  And a closed loop cognitive assessment system will be designed and implemented to understand and monitor a child's progress over time and provide recommendations and decision support to cognitive experts so they can make better treatment decisions.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

The objective of this project is to advance our understanding of how physical exercises can be used to assess and train cognitive skills, by developing novel computer vision and data mining methods to analyze body motion data as a user performs certain tasks.For this purpose, the project team created an integrated, low cost assessment system, called ATEC(Activate Test of Embodied Cognition), that can be used in schools and clinics.ATEC provides easy to understand age related assessments of embodied cognition. These assessments can be used repeatedly to determine the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving executive functioning in children.

Motivation

There are millions of children with special learning needs who can benefit from the outcomes of this research because their executive function abilities can now be diagnosed, scored, and treated in a personalized way, thus offering targeted intervention.

Summary of Activities

Project activities include the development and evaluation of a set of specially designed physical exercises for children to quantitatively assess how well they perform the exercises and tp correlate physical exercise performance with the children's cognitive skills(called embodied cognition). New computer vision and data mining methods were developed toanalyze the motion of children performing exercises andto provide automatic and accurate measurements of various metrics of performance, including metrics explicitly defined by experts, and metrics related to generic motion features.Data mining methods were developed and used to identify statistically significant correlations between metrics of physical performance and motion data collected from the children being involved in physical tasks.Correlations were made between such metrics and changes in the cognitive skills of children over time.Graphicaluser interfaces were developed to guide the non-technical teacher/expert and the parents, on how to use the system. Multi-sensing and multiplatform game interfaces were developed for special cognitive cases.

Project Outcomes and Findings

The ATEC system(Activate Test of Embodied Cognition)was used to collect and evaluate data embodied cognition data from children aged 5 to 11 over time.ATEC enabled automated assessment system for embodied cognition in children, providing accurate executive functioning ability diagnosis from motion data.It was demonstrated that the ATEC system has discriminant validity between children at risk for Executive Function-related impairments and children who are not. Supervised Machine Learning methods were developed that use deep learning algorithms to extract human body posesto analyze collected ATEC videos. Self-supervised machine learning methods were developed that exploit unlabeled data to reduce the need for manual annotation of data. An advanced interface was developed for the ATEC system to be used by non-technical caregivers to test executive function ability of children. The Cogbeacon multimodal dataset, a public dataset, was developed to assess Cognitive Fatigue. An open-source data collection platform was developed to assess cognitive functionalities

Intellectual Merit

The project developed a computational system based on embodied cognition that provided an accurate way to diagnose executive function, beyond the traditional manual methods which have a lot of bias and variability. The project developed a new type of human resource, that of using embodied cognition to assess the mental capabilities of attention and executive function of children, enhancing access to education for children with special learning needs and supporting the work of teachers. The project created valuable research resources that include research datasets, task scenarios and compelling user interfaces. Human centered interfaces were developed to enable caregivers to interact with children in a consistent and standard way, as well as provide children with a visual a guide of what they have to do

Broader Impacts

Vital to effective teaching and learning is the ability to understand the cognitive abilities of children to pay attention, follow directions, and be engaged. This project provided a transformative new way to assess these parameters accurately and to personalize the potential interventions needed to teach of a child. Furthermore, the project advanced the state of the art of computer vision and data mining algorithms to enable a totally new way of understanding human cognition by analyzing the physical motion data of children performing certain exercises, thus enhancing the accuracy and time of executive function assessment. Many publications were produced from this project and project results were integrated into advanced Human Computer Interaction classes. The project disseminated its results widely and supported the graduation of seven Ph.D. students who presented their work at peer review conferences. The ATEC(Activate Test of Embodied Cognition) has the potential to become a low-cost commercial technology product with broad use in schools and vocational training settings.
